sn35.80:4.1: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha …
sn35.80:4.3: “Sir, is there one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge?”
sn35.80:7.1: “Ignorance is one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge.”
sn35.80:8.1: “But how does a mendicant know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”
sn35.80:9.3: When a mendicant has heard that
sn35.80:9.4: nothing is worth clinging on to,
sn35.80:9.5: they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Completely understanding all things, they see all signs as other. They see the eye, sights,
sn35.80:9.8: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as other. …
sn35.80:9.12: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as other.
sn35.80:9.13: That’s how a mendicant knows and sees so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”
